title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and provides a basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, specifying that specific information from a credible source must be received within 15 days for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General will close the matter if there is no evidence of violation within 15 days. If evidence is found, a preliminary investigation will begin. Section 592(c)(2) of title 28, United States Code, requires specific information from a credible source for the Attorney General to act. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel is defined with specificity and limited to alleged violations of criminal law requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute these violations and related matters. The independent counsel's jurisdiction is limited to alleged criminal violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. Amendments specify that the counsel can investigate and prosecute these violations and related matters. The independent counsel has authorities and duties related to investigating and prosecuting alleged criminal violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. The independent counsel is provided with office space within a Federal building, unless determined otherwise by the Administrator of General Services. Compliance with Department of Justice policies is amended to ensure enforcement of criminal laws and release of information. Limitations on expenditures are also outlined. Limitation on Expenditures: No funds may be spent on an independent counsel office after 2 years unless specified in a later appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The amendment allows for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. The termination of an independent counsel's office can be initiated by the court, Attorney General, or the subject of an investigation after 2 years if the investigation is completed. The independent counsel's investigation may be completed by the Department of Justice if deemed appropriate. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. Periodic reappointment of the independent counsel is outlined in the amendment. The independent counsel must apply for reappointment every 2 years, with the court determining if the office should be terminated. If not terminated, the court will reappoint the current counsel or appoint a qualified replacement within 90 days after the end of the 2-year period. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, with recommendations to enhance cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
